case_name: Legal representatives of Ram Cheej Pandey v. Lachhman Singh and others

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1308 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1308 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 7,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated December 7, 1966 of Allahabad High Court in Appeal No. 5252 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 7, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Appeal No. 5252 of 1960. B. Agarwal and K. P. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed decisions of trial court and first appellate court and awarded decree for possession to plaintiff-respondents against defendant-appellants.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of Allahabad High Court whereby that Court reversed the decisions of the trial Court and the first appellate companyrt and awarded a decree for the possession of the land in dispute in favour of the plaintiff-respondents against the defendant-appellants.

facts.text: Appellants entitled to withdraw mortgage amount deposited by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were further held to be entitled to withdraw the mortgage amount which had been deposited by the respondents.

facts.text: On January 16, 1923 Ganga Prasad Rai, father of Lachhman Singh plaintiff-respondent No. 7, executed mortgage deed for Rs. 600 in favour of Ram Cheej Pandey and put him in possession as mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1923 Ganga Prasad Rai, father of Lachhman Singh plaintiff-respondent No. 7, executed a mortgage deed in respect of land in dispute for Rs. 600 in favour of Ram Cheej Pandey and put him in possession thereof as a mortgagee.

facts.text: Ganga Prasad Rai was the occupancy tenant of the land in dispute at the time of the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Ganga Prasad Rai at the time of the mortgage was the occupancy tenant of the land in dispute.

facts.text: Ram Cheej Pandey is dead and appellants are his legal representatives, impleaded as defendants.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Cheej Pandey, who was impleaded as defendant No. 1 in the suit, is number dead and the appellants, who too were impleaded as defendants, are his legal representatives.

facts.text: On January 6, 1955 plaintiff-respondents No. 1 to 6 along with Lachhman Singh plaintiff No. 7 filed suit for possession of land against Ram Cheej Pandey and others.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1955 plaintiff-respondents No. 1 to 6 along with Lachhman Singh plaintiff No. 7 filed the present suit for possession of the land in dispute against Rain Cheej Pandey and others

facts.text: Lachhman Singh transferred all his rights in the land with consent and permission of the Zamindar to plaintiffs 1 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that Lachhman Singh had transferred all his rights in the land with the companysent and permission of the Zamindar  the land-lord  in favour of plaintiffs to .

facts.text: Plaintiffs 1 to 6 became occupancy tenants and acquired Bhumidari rights by depositing ten times the land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated that, as a result of the said transfer, plaintiffs 1 to 6 had become the occupancy tenants of the land in dispute. The plaintiffs 1 to 6 also claimed to have acquired Bhumidari rights of the land by depositing ten times the- amount of the land revenue.

facts.text: Plaintiffs deposited mortgage amount in court as mortgagee not prepared to return land.

anchor.surface_text: According to the plaintiffs, they had a right to redeem the land from the mortgagee, but as the mortgagee was number prepared to give back the land on receipt of the mortgage money, the plain- tiffs were depositing the amount in companyrt.

facts.text: Raj Narain Pandey admitted the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Raj Narain Pandey admitted the mortgage alleged by the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Defendants averred plaintiffs 1 to 6 had no right to redeem and suit barred by limitation due to adverse possession over 12 years.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, averred that plaintiffs 1 to 6 had numberright to redeem the land. The plaintiffs suit was further stated to be barred by limitation as, according to the written statement, the defendants were in adverse possession of the land for more than 12 years.

facts.text: Trial court found suit not barred by time but plaintiffs had no right to sue, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found that the plaintiffs suit was number barred by time. The plaintiffs were, however, held to have numberright to sue. In the result, the suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Additional Civil Judge Ballia held plaintiffs 1 to 6 not successors of plaintiff No. 7, defendants trespassers, suit barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, learned Additional Civil Judge Ballia held that plaintiffs 1 to 6 were number the successors of plaintiff No. It was further observed that the defendants, after the mortgage, had become trespassers in the land and the suit against them was barred by time.

facts.text: High Court held in 1946 plaintiffs 1 to 6 acquired same rights as plaintiff No. 7 had before surrender via agreement with Zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter was taken up in second appeal before the High Court, the learned Judge held that in 1946 plaintiffs 1 to 6 had acquired, as a result of agreement with the Zamindar, the same rights which had vested in plaintiff No. 7 before he surrendered those rights.

facts.text: Compromise decree dated January 4, 1946/February 2, 1945 in suit by plaintiffs 1 to 6 against landlords and Lachhman Singh accepted plaintiffs 1 to 6 as occupancy tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The companyy of the companypromise decree dated January 4, 1946/February 2, 1945 has been placed on record, and it would appear therefrom that in a suit brought by the plaintiff-respondents 1 to 6 against the landlords and Lachhman Singh  who was described in that suit as Lachhman Rai , the plaintiffs 1 to 6 were accepted to be occupancy tenants of the land in dispute.

facts.text: Sanad dated October 5, 1949 declared plaintiffs 1 to 6 as Bhumidars of the land.

anchor.surface_text: The material on record also indicates that plaintiff-respondents 1 to 6 have been declared to be the Bhumidars of the land in dispute. Sanad dated October 5, 1949 declaring them to be Bhumidars of the land was issued on October 5, 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondents 1 to 6 entitled to redeem the mortgage under section 91 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: As plaintiff respondents 1 to 6 were the occupancy tenants of the land in dispute and as they were declared to be Bhumidars, they had, in our opinion, sufficient interest in the land as clothed them with the right to redeem it from the mortgagees.

holdings.text: Plaintiff-respondents 1 to 6 were entitled to redeem the mortgage and recover possession as they had sufficient interest in the land under section 91(a) of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: As plaintiff respondents 1 to 6 were the occupancy tenants of the land in dispute and as they were declared to be Bhumidars, they had, in our opinion, sufficient interest in the land as clothed them with the right to redeem it from the mortgagees. Clause a of section 91 of the Transfer of Property Act provides, inter alia, that any person other than the mortgagee of the interest sought to be redeemed who has any interest in, or charge upon the property mortgaged or in or upon the right to redeem the same, may institute a suit for redemption of the mortgaged property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs were occupancy tenants via compromise decree and declared Bhumidars, giving interest to redeem under s.91(a) TPA.

holdings.text: The suit is not barred by limitation as mortgagee possession over 12 years does not extinguish the mortgagor's right to redeem but only prescribes mortgagee rights.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to the above contention, because we find that the matter is covered by two Full Bench decisions of the Allahabad High Court. In a five-judge decision of the Allahabad High Court in the case of Mahabal Singh and Anr. v. Ram Raj and Ors. supra, the court referred to the decision of a three-judge bench of that court in the case of Ghassu and Anr. v. Babu Ram and Anr. supra and found that the following five propositions had been laid down in the earlier case: That the usufructuary mortgage of an occupancy holding by a tenant is void and not voidable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governed by Full Bench decisions of Allahabad HC which lay down that such possession prescribes only mortgagee rights; correctness not questioned.

holdings.text: Surrender of occupancy rights by original tenant did not extinguish the mortgage; defendants' possession remained analogous to that of mortgagees.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the above mentioned Full Bench decisions, it cannot, be disputed that the status of the defendant- appellants was analogous to that of mortgagees. It also cannot be disputed that the successor of the original mortgagor would be entitled to recover possession of the mortgaged land from the defendant-appellants on payment of the mortgage money.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full Bench propositions apply; surrender does not affect mortgage relationship which is analogous to mortgagor-mortgagee.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs 1 to 6 are successors entitled to redeem as occupancy tenants via compromise decree simultaneous with surrender.

anchor.surface_text: The copy of the compromise decree dated January 4, 1946/February 2, 1945 has been placed on record, and it would appear therefrom that in a suit brought by the plaintiff-respondents 1 to 6 against the landlords and Lachhman Singh who was described in that suit as Lachhman Rai, the plaintiffs 1 to 6 were accepted to be occupancy tenants of the land in dispute. The effect of that decree was that while the occupancy rights of Lachhman Singh came to an end, those of plaintiff- respondents 1 to 6 came into existence at the same time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compromise decree accepts plaintiffs as occupancy tenants at time of surrender, vesting same rights.

holdings.text: Suit for redemption and possession of occupancy mortgaged land is maintainable in civil court.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that no such plea was taken in the written statement or in the trial court or the first appellate court, we find that the five-judge bench of the Allahabad High Court in the case of Mahabal Singh and Anr. supra has held that such a suit is maintainable in a civil court. We see no cogent ground to disturb that view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Held maintainable by Allahabad HC Full Bench; no cogent ground to disturb.

holdings.text: In interpretation of local statutes, High Court view over years should be followed per stare decisis to avoid uncertainty.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Agarwal has not questioned the correctness of the above mentioned five propositions and, in our opinion, rightly so. In the matter of the interpretation of a local statute, the view taken by the High Court over a number of years should normally be adhered to and not disturbed. A different view would not only introduce an element of uncertainty and confusion, it would also have the effect of unsettling transactions which might have been entered into on the faith of those decisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy of certainty and reliance interests; quoted authorities support.

precedents.citation: Ghassu and Anr. v. Babu Ram and Anr.  1

anchor.surface_text: Ghassu and Anr. v. Babu Ram and Anr.  1

precedents.case_name: Ghassu and Anr. v. Babu Ram and Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: Usufructuary mortgage of an occupancy holding is void; mortgagor cannot recover possession without paying mortgage money; mortgagee's possession over 12 years prescribes only mortgagee rights without extinguishing mortgagor's redemption right; mortgagor can file redemption suit; relationship analogous to mortgagor-mortgagee.
precedents.cited_holding: That the usufructuary mortgage of an occupancy holding by a tenant is void and not voidable. That a mortgagor after giving possession to the mortgagee cannot recover possession of the holding without paying the money which he had taken from the mortgagee. That a mortgagee of an occupancy holding by remaining in possession for over 12 years does not extinguish the rights of the mortgagor to redeem him and by such possession the mortgagee only prescribes for mortgagee rights. That it is open to the mortgagor to seek possession of the holding by tendering the consideration which he had received and he may do so by a redemption suit. The relationship which comes into existence as a result of the mortgage of an occupancy holding and its possession being transferred to the mortgagee, though not strictly speaking that of a mortgagor and a mortgagee, is analogous to that relationship, and the action which is raised by the mortgagor to recover possession of the holding on payment of the money due to the mortgagee, though not strictly in the nature of a redemption, is analogous to a redemption suit.

precedents.citation: Mahabal Singh and Anr. v. Ram Raj and Ors.  2

precedents.case_name: Brownsea Haven Properties v. Poole Corpn.
precedents.cited_proposition: A decision of long standing on the basis of which many persons will in the course of time have arranged their affairs should not lightly be disturbed by a superior court not strictly bound by the decision.
precedents.cited_holding: there is well-established authority for the view that a decision of long standing on the basis of which many persons will in the course of time have arranged their affairs should not lightly be disturbed by a superior court not strictly bound itself by the decision.

precedents.cited_proposition: Suit for possession on redemption maintainable in civil court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed with costs, upholding decree for possession of the land in favour of plaintiff-respondents and allowing them to redeem the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: As plaintiff respondents 1 to 6 were the occupancy tenants of the land in dispute and as they were declared to be Bhumidars, they had, in our opinion, sufficient interest in the land as clothed them with the right to redeem it from the mortgagees. Clause a of section 91 of the Transfer of Property Act provides, inter alia, that any person other than the mortgagee of the interest sought to be redeemed who has any interest in, or charge upon the property mortgaged or in or upon the right to redeem the same, may institute a suit for redemption of the mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to the above contention, because we find that the matter is covered by two Full Bench decisions of the Allahabad High Court. In a five-judge decision of the Allahabad High Court in the case of Mahabal Singh and Anr. v. Ram Raj and Ors. supra, the court referred to the decision of a three-judge bench of that court in the case of Ghassu and Anr. v. Babu Ram and Anr. supra and found that the following five propositions had been laid down in the earlier case: That the usufructuary mortgage of an occupancy holding by a tenant is void and not voidable.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 undercuts concept c4 by determining that surrender of tenancy rights under Section 45(c) does not extinguish the mortgage, with defendants' possession continuing as mortgagees.
The holding states defendants' possession remained analogous to mortgagees, undercutting the applicability of Section 180 which targets unauthorized possession for ejectment.
By holding that defendants' possession remained analogous to mortgagees and not extinguished, the applicability of the two-year limitation under c7 for s.180 suits is undercut.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the above mentioned Full Bench decisions, it cannot, be disputed that the status of the defendant- appellants was analogous to that of mortgagees. It also cannot be disputed that the successor of the original mortgagor would be entitled to recover possession of the mortgaged land from the defendant-appellants on payment of the mortgage money.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The copy of the compromise decree dated January 4, 1946/February 2, 1945 has been placed on record, and it would appear therefrom that in a suit brought by the plaintiff-respondents 1 to 6 against the landlords and Lachhman Singh who was described in that suit as Lachhman Rai, the plaintiffs 1 to 6 were accepted to be occupancy tenants of the land in dispute. The effect of that decree was that while the occupancy rights of Lachhman Singh came to an end, those of plaintiff- respondents 1 to 6 came into existence at the same time.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that no such plea was taken in the written statement or in the trial court or the first appellate court, we find that the five-judge bench of the Allahabad High Court in the case of Mahabal Singh and Anr. supra has held that such a suit is maintainable in a civil court. We see no cogent ground to disturb that view.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
